user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GenericClose_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_GenericClose_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                             result;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    result = close(impl->fd);
    if (result < 0)
    {
        /*
         * close() can technically fail for various reasons, but
         * there isn't much recourse if this call fails.  Just log
         * the failure for debugging.
         *
         * POSIX also does not specify the state of the filehandle
         * after a close() with an error.
         *
         * At least in  Linux/glibc the filehandle is always closed
         * in the kernel and should not be used again or re-closed.
         */
        OS_DEBUG("close: %s\n", strerror(errno));
    }
    impl->fd = -1;
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_GenericClose_Impl:
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
All other lines in the function do not call or use any of the string handling functions from <string.h> and therefore are not relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. Specifically:
- The call to close(impl->fd) and the assignment impl->fd = -1 do not perform any string operations or pointer-based string accesses.
- The use of OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and the access to the impl structure (impl->fd) are simple object/table/index operations and do not involve functions from <string.h>.
- The typedef and the external table declaration only define types and storage; they do not perform string accesses.
The only code that could involve <string.h> string handling is the OS_DEBUG call that invokes strerror(errno) and the OS_DEBUG macro itself (which may expand to logging code that uses string functions). Those fragments are therefore listed for investigation.
